biography: Matthew Caesar is a Professor at the University of Illinois, focusing on the design, analysis, and implementation of distributed systems and networks on a large scale. His research emphasizes network operations, measurement, and availability, particularly in improving the reliability and performance of the Internet infrastructure, including routing, DNS, and data centers. He is also the Chair of ACM SIGCOMM and co-chair of The Networking Channel, and has co-founded Veriflow, which was sold to VMware in 2019.
researchStatement: Improving the robustness of computer systems and networks through principles of softwarization and programmability, enabling the use of techniques from the field of software engineering and AI to build highly functional and reliable systems. Focuses on developing novel data structures and algorithms to represent complicated system functions in ways that enable highly scalable formal reasoning about the behaviors of those systems, enabling verification of safety properties, checking of possible future behaviors, and deriving system configurations with desirable safety properties.
